attributes.description: New York City, surrounded by wharves and commerce
Extreme downtown of Manhattan, washed by waves
The sea as a source of fascination, danger, and meaning
Symbolic of life, meditation, and mystery

attributes.role: Mythological figure associated with self-reflection and loss

entities.name: Grand Contested Election for the Presidency of the United States

attributes.description: Historical/political event referenced as part of cosmic order
Portentous and mysterious monster; primary cause of Ishmael’s voyage

attributes.text: Ishmael introduces himself and explains his impulse to go to sea, culminating in his decision to embark on a whaling voyage driven by fascination with the whale and destiny.
Moby-Dick explores obsession, fate, and humanity’s relationship with the sea and the unknown.

relationships.context: Ishmael goes to sea when depressed or restless.
The Manhattoes are described as being surrounded by commerce and the ocean.
Ishmael insists on going to sea as a sailor, not passenger, captain, or cook.
Ishmael attributes his voyage to the Fates’ program of destiny.
The mysterious whale was chief among the motives for Ishmael’s decision.
Chapter 1 summary ties Ishmael’s personal motives to the cosmic theme of destiny and whales.
Ishmael associates water with human longing, meditation, and life’s phantom-like nature.
Book-wide summary places Ishmael’s voyage within larger meanings of fate and obsession.

concept_groups.name: Fate and Destiny
concept_groups.description: Ishmael interprets his journey as predestined, connected to the Fates and the whale.

concept_groups.name: Water and Life
concept_groups.description: Water symbolizes mystery, human longing, reflection, and the essence of life.

concept_groups.name: Escape and Restlessness
concept_groups.description: Ishmael goes to sea as a counterbalance to melancholy and restlessness.
